p: Free radicals are molecular species or atoms which contain one or more unpaired electrons. These are constantly produced in the human body as a result of cell metabolism [ 3]. Free radicals have important roles in gene expression and activation of receptors as well as in regulation of signal transduction [ 4]. However, an excess of free radicals can become toxic to living cells [ 5] and may cause many diseases such as cancer, atherosclerosis, neurodegenerative diseases, and inflammation [ 6â€“ 8].
